detail.content: Global Public Health / History Joint Major    | Department of History | New York University                                    NEW YORK UNIVERSITY     ARTS AND SCIENCE     COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCE     GRADUATE SCHOOL OF ARTS AND SCIENCE             Department of History     Arts & Science                      Back to Home       Global Public Health / History Joint Major      About the Major:    The History Department has teamed up with NYU’s Global Institute of Public Health to develop a joint major in Global Public Health/History . This major offers the opportunity for students to deepen their understandings of issues related to public health, while also combining an interest in history, broadly defined, with preparation for a wide range of graduate programs and professional careers.          Majors in GPH/History have considerable freedom in their selection of History courses, not all of which need to have a strict public health dimension. Your advisors in the History Department will be happy to work with you in order to develop a program that complements and deepens your interests in public health – through such resources as internships, independent studies, and, for those who qualify, the honors thesis. For a course planning form that gives a sense of the shape of the GPH/History major, click here .     Declaring the Major:                      In order to declare the joint Global Public Health/History major, you must complete the  Declaration of Major Form for Global Public Health/History and submit it to the Undergraduate Administrative Assistant in the History Department.       Global Public Health/History Course Offerings:       Below are just some of the History Department’s offerings that are relevant to the GPH/History major. For questions related to the course of study and requirements, you may contact the Director of Undergraduate Studies (Professor Ortolano, ortolano@nyu.edu ) or the Undergraduate Program Assistant (Chelsea Rhodes, chelsea.rhodes@nyu.edu ).     HIST-UA 115: Environmental History of the Early Modern World HIST-UA 127: Living & Working in Early Modern Europe HIST-UA 135: Science & Society in Early Modern Europe (Pre-Modern Science) HIST-UA 150: Nature & Society: An Environmental History of Modern Europe  HIST-UA 158: History of Medicine HIST-UA 175: Freud's Vienna HIST-UA 188: Women & Gender in Modern Europe HIST-UA 196: Women in European Society HIST-UA 202: History of Western Medicine HIST-UA 215: Science & the Humanities HIST-UA 279: Public Health in Early Modern Europe HIST-UA 280: Family & Sexuality in Medieval Europe HIST-UA 283: The Origin of Humanity: A Modern Obsession HIST-UA 293: Global Medicine & Disease: The Challenges We Face HIST-UA 310: History of the Body HIST-UA 533: Gender & Sexuality in Latin America HIST-UA 545: Race, Disease, and Asia America HIST-UA 547: Food & Drugs in Chinese History HIST-UA 595: North American Environmental History HIST-UA 596: Environmental History of NYC HIST-UA 634: Power & Poverty HIST-UA 655: Race, Gender, & Sexuality in the U.S. HIST-UA 658: Studying Gender & Sexuality HIST-UA 750: American Environmental History HIST-UA 750: Yoga & Tantra: In History and Today HIST-UA 799: Famine & the Irish Diaspora HIST-UA 811: History of Sexuality HIST-UA 830: The History of Water                 Contact Us | © New York University , Arts and Science

Brigitte Miriam Bedos-Rezak     Professor of History   Email:     bbr2@nyu.edu     Field:   Medieval Europe   Research Interests:   History and Theory; Semiotic Anthropology; Material Culture; Media and Communication; Historical Anthropology of the Middle Ages; Medieval France; Medieval Sign Theory; Medieval Diplomatics and Sigillography; Latin and Old French Paleography               Thomas Bender     University Professor of the Humanities;   Professor of History   Email:     thomas.bender@nyu.edu     Field:   United States   Research Interests:   U.S. intellectual and cultural history, 1750-present; intellectuals and cities; transnational and global approaches to U.S. history; historiography.             Ruth Ben-Ghiat     Professor of Italian and History   Email:     rb68@nyu.edu     Field:   Modern Europe   Research Interests:   Ruth Ben-Ghiat is Professor of History and Italian Studies. A specialist in 20th century European history, with Italy a particular focus, she writes on war, including the relationship of war and cinema; empires; and fascist regimes. She is a regular contributor on these subjects to the Huffington Post and CNN.com. Follow her @ruthbenghiat.              Zvi Ben-Dor Benite     Chair; Middle Eastern and Islamic Studies;   Professor of History and Middle Eastern and Islamic Studies   Email:     zbd1@nyu.edu     Field:   East Asia   Research Interests:   Global History, Early Modern and Modern Chinese History, Asian and European Islam, Religion and World History, Middle Eastern History, History of Geography, Arab-Jewish and Mizrahi History             Lauren Benton     Silver Professor; Affiliate Professor of Law;   Professor of History   Email:     lauren.benton@nyu.edu     Field:   Atlantic World   Research Interests:   Atlantic world, legal history, comparative history of empires. Andrew Sartori     Associate Professor of History   Email:     asartori@nyu.edu     Field:   South Asia   Research Interests:   Modern South Asia, Modern Intellectual History, Social Theory             John Shovlin     Associate Professor of History   Email:     john.shovlin@nyu.edu     Field:   Early Modern Europe   Research Interests:   Political and cultural history of ancien régime Europe, particularly France; the French Revolution; history of political economy; aristocratic culture and politics; international politics and international political thought in eighteenth-century Europe; the Franco-British relationship.
